text:
The surprising benefits of sharing your data projects in public — even if no one engages.

When I started sharing projects on LinkedIn, I barely got any likes.

But I kept going — and here's what happened:
 - I got better at explaining my thinking
 - People started DM'ing me about my process
 - I built a visible body of work, even before interviews

Public work compounds.
Even when it’s quiet.

You’re not just building content.
You’re building clarity, trust, and visibility.

Don’t wait until you “feel ready.”
Post while you’re learning.

🕒 Two hours’ notice for an interview. Out of town. No reschedule allowed.

Yes, that just happened.

Recently, I was contacted by an organization I had previously interviewed with.

They invited me for a second interview but with only a 2-hour notice, while I was out of town and unavailable.

I politely declined and requested a reschedule, but unfortunately, the response was a firm no.

That moment reminded me of how important it is for both candidates and employers to value each other's time, availability, and communication.

Most of us are balancing multiple responsibilities while job searching, and flexibility on both sides goes a long way.

I just want to remind jobseekers that it's okay to set boundaries. You're not “missing an opportunity” by expecting basic respect, you’re standing in your worth.

If a company can't respect your time, your availability, or even offer basic courtesy like scheduling notice, imagine what it would be like working with them long-term. 🚩

Have you ever experienced a situation like this?

#VirtualAssistant #Jobseekers #ExecutiveAssistant
Just saw a LinkedIn Influencer with 'Organic Growth' written in the profile with 65K+ followers claiming that he can help you in growing your platform, copying the posts from other influencers.

Jobseekers, this one’s for you.
 Every application, every interview, every follow-up… the pressure is immense.
 And I know what you're thinking: Am I not good enough? 
 But let me tell you, this isn’t about you or your skills. It’s about a broken system where 60% of applicants never hear back. 
 Your mental health is not worth sacrificing for a system that doesn’t acknowledge your worth. 
 Please remember, taking care of yourself is the real priority. 
 Your dream job will come, but for now, breathe. 🌻
Looking for jobs on LinkedIn is like online dating: Full of promises, but in the end, you’re just left ghosted.

LinkedIn scams be like: 'Congratulations, you've been selected for a role you didn’t even apply for!' 
 The catch? Pay Rs. 50,000 for the honor.

Next time when I'll be reading some LinkedIn Influencer's story, I am starting from the last line.
If there's a link attached to it, it's most probably a fake one.
Saves me time!

sapana dekhnu ramro kura ho,
tara job ko sapana dekhera 'interested' lekhnu,
yo ta ramro kura vayena ni?

Every time I poured my heart into 5-6 rounds of interviews and faced rejection, it felt like a punch in the gut. The sleepless nights, the endless preparation, all for nothing.

But looking back, I realize it wasn’t nothing. It was the Universe’s way of saying, “Not this one, something better is on the way.”

Every single time, I’ve been shown why that rejection happened.

Doors I thought I wanted to walk through were shut, only to have the right ones swing open.

The kind that aligned with my growth, my values, and my happiness.

At first, it stung. It hurt deeply. But now, when things don’t go as planned, I don’t panic.

I don’t question my worth. I sit back, breathe, and trust. The Universe knows.

I know there's another plan waiting. Something bigger, better, and just for me.

To anyone feeling the weight of rejection: trust that the closed doors are protecting you from something you can’t see right now.

Your path is being cleared for something even more beautiful.

To everyone who's still looking for a job...

I see you. I feel you. 💔

Every rejection email feels like a punch in the gut, and every 'We'll get back to you' sounds more like 'You'll never hear from us.'

But I want you to know, you're not alone in this. 🌸

According to a study, 80% of jobseekers struggle with anxiety and self-doubt during their search. It's normal to feel lost, but it's not the end.

Take breaks, breathe, and remember, this doesn't define you. Your worth is not tied to an offer letter. 💥

Your mental health matters more than any job.

Sometimes, we forget that a company’s brand name doesn’t define someone’s talent. It’s easy to get caught up in the 'big company = big talent' mindset, but that's not always the case.

I’ve had the privilege of working with people from smaller companies (lesser known) who blow me away with their skills and dedication. They don’t need a fancy title or a famous brand behind them to prove their worth.

I've seen the other side too—people in top-tier companies feeling lost, overwhelmed, or stuck, even though the world sees them as 'successful'.

Let’s stop attaching someone’s value to the company they work for. Freshers especially need to hear this—skills are what matter, not the size of the company behind them.

At the end of the day, happiness and growth don’t come from a brand name, they come from doing what you love and constantly improving your craft.

So when I left a toxic work environment, I told my manager a simple thing and felt so good 😯

I just said-

'Hope your son gets a manager like you.
I hope that the manager behaves the same way as you did with me.
Thank you.'

Now tell me 1 thing-

She always said that she was a great manager.
Why will she get offended?

I just told her that I wish her son would get a manager like she was.

If you felt bad, then that means you were a bad manager and now you know it. � 80

If you feel good, then take it as a blessing for your son and you'll really want someone to treat your son/daughter in the same way.

She cannot be even angry with me else it'll prove that she was not a 'great' manager.

Muskan - 1
Manager - 0

Muskan -> Aura +100000000

(Fictional message unfortunately :(
)

Hope you all become the people that your sons/daughters will like to work under 🙏

There are a lot of bad people/things, bring a small change and break the chain :)

Interviewer: “You’ve had a career break. That’s a red flag.”

Candidate: “I took time off to care for my family. During that time, I kept learning—certifications, coding, mentoring. I wasn’t on a payroll, but I never stopped growing.”

Interviewer: “Still, we can only offer 50k. Standard for someone re-entering.”

He politely declined.

Two weeks later, another company saw his skills, resilience, and strength.
They offered him 85k, flexibility, and respect.

Moral: A gap in a resume isn’t a gap in capability.
Hire for potential, not just presence.
People are more than their timelines.

People who respect themselves get respect from others.

I dread survey data.

Why?

• One row per person, but every question gets its own column
• Multiple-choice responses split across q5_option1, q5_option2, q5_option3
• Text-based responses like “Describe your experience with our service” that turn into data cleaning nightmares
• Typos, inconsistent formatting, random spacing… fun stuff

Before I can even analyze anything, I spend hours wrangling formats, renaming columns, merging values, and flattening response sets.

Power BI and Tableau don’t love it either. Wide formats slow everything down.

It’s not the insights I mind — it’s how much cleaning you have to do to get to them.

What’s been your experience with messy survey data? Any tricks that save time or headaches?

We’ve all heard the debate:
"Why pay for university when Google and YouTube are free?"

Having just completed my Diploma in Data Technologies, here’s why I believe formal education still matters—with a reality check:

✅ The Undeniable Advantages
1. Structure Over Chaos
No more "tutorial hopping" or wondering what to learn next
A curated syllabus covers SQL, Python, visualization, and stats—no gaps

2. Instant Access to Mentors
My lecturers had 10–15 years of industry experience
Got answers to "Why does this matter in the real world?" instantly

3. Built-in Accountability
Class WhatsApp groups kept me motivated (shared struggles > solo grinding)
Deadlines forced consistency (no "I’ll finish this tutorial someday")

4. Credibility That Opens Doors
In 3/3 tech interviews I had, recruiters specifically praised:
"We respect that you pursued formal upskilling"
Certificates won’t get you hired, but they get you noticed

⚠️ The Catch
Formal education is just the foundation. You still need to:
Build projects (theory ≠ hands-on skills)
Network aggressively (your degree won’t land you jobs—people will)
Keep learning (tools evolve faster than curricula)

My Verdict
University is worth it IF:
You thrive with structure
You leverage mentors (not just slides)
You treat it as step 1, not the finish line

Self-learning is better IF:
You’re highly disciplined
You’re targeting specific tools (e.g., "Learn Power BI in 8 weeks")
You’re supplementing with certifications (Google Data Analytics, etc.)

What’s your take?
Formal degree or self-taught—what’s worked for you?
